newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Zimbabwe ex-president faces more sex accusations.
newsitem.headline: Zimbabwe ex-president faces more sex accusations.

text.p: Former Zimbabwe president Canaan Banana, under investigation on allegations of raping and forcing an aide into a homosexual relationship, is facing more accusations of sodomy, a police official said on Thursday.

The official, who declined to be named, confirmed a report by Zimbabwe's independent Financial Gazette newspaper that dozens of current and former students from Harare's University of Zimbabwe and some state security force members made the allegations before a police panel in the past two months.

"Yes, it's true that the panel has interviewed dozens of people charging that they were sodomised and abused. Others allege they were witnesses to such acts of homosexuality," the officer told Reuters.
"There are so many cases and we are still investigating," he said, refusing to go into details.
The Financial Gazette quoted highly placed police sources as saying the investigating team was overwhelmed but had isolated eight complaints for further inquiry.
"Hopefully, we will have the matter heard in court within the next four weeks. Banana has been extremely cooperative with the investigations taking place," it quoted one of the sources as saying.
Banana's lawyers declined to comment on the issue, saying it was sub judice.

Banana, a 61-year-old Methodist minister, came under police investigation after accusations by his former aide de camp Jefta Dube, 35, that he raped and forced him into a homosexual relationship during his presidency in the 1980s.
Dube was sentenced to 10 years in jail in February for the 1995 fatal shooting of a fellow policeman who goaded him by calling him "Banana's wife".

Dube told the high court that his subjugation by Banana, a largely ceremonial president for seven years until 1987, made him depressive and an alcoholic. Judge David Bartlett ruled that Dube's case should be treated as one of diminished responsibility.
The judge said the Dube's charges against Banana were probably true and ordered police to investigate further.
Dube last month sued Banana for damage claims of Z$1.3 million (U.S.$115,044).

The Financial Gazette said the police had interviewed Vice-President Simon Muzenda, Justice Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa, former army commander Solomon Mujuru and ex-police commissioner Henry Mukurazhizha, all named by Dube as being aware of his complaints against Banana.
